tag.name: caption
tag.description: The caption tag is only used to provide a caption for a figure, subfigure, or a table. You can enter a somewhat lengthy description of the figure with the caption tag. In contrast, using the title tag you can enter only a brief title or label that appears above a figure.

table.caption: Figure 1: This dog is sitting, unlike some dogs.

img.alt: A dog sitting on a bed

tag.name: code
tag.description: The code tag is used to insert a line or block of computer code (for example a command) into a document.

exampleexample.input: Enter the command ls /etc to get a listing of configuration files.

output.p: Enter the command ls /etc to get a listing of configuration files.

exampleexample.input: function popUp() { var popmsg = 'Hello & goodbye'; alert($popmsg); }

tag.p: Note that ampersand and angle bracket characters (&, <, and >) must be escaped (what's this?). Their escaped equivalents are &, <, and >, respectively. Alternatively, one can insert <![CDATA[ before the code text and ]]> after it (what's this?) to eliminate the need for escaping.

values.value: The code will be included in the current line of text (default).
The code will be set apart from the surrounding text. If the display attribute is set to "block", then an id is required.
The code will not be displayed.

attributes.attribute: Defines the language contained within the code block, e.g. "PHP," "Visual C#," or "FORTRAN."

tag.name: example
tag.description: The example tag is used to contain an example of something. This is especially useful in connection with the definition tag where it can be used to give an example of the meaning of a term.

exampleexample.input: <example id="lincoln-example"> <para id="lincoln-para"> The Lincoln Memorial is an example of a monument. </para> </example>

div.p: The Lincoln Memorial is an example of a monument.

attributes.attribute: Defines the type of example in order to give specialized control over numbering. Examples of the same type are labeled in series (i.e., Example 1, Example 2...). Type can be used in conjunction with label so that examples of each user-defined type appear with their own label. Type can be any user-defined value that reflects the purpose of the example.

tag.name: exercise
tag.description: The exercise tag is used to present a question or task to the reader, with an optional answer hidden from view until the reader wants to reveal it. The question or task is contained within a problem tag and the answer is contained within a solution tag, both of which are inside the exercise tag.

exampleexample.input: <exercise id="texas-exercise"> <problem id="texas-problem"> <para id="texas-problem-para"> What is the capital of Texas? </para> </problem> <solution id="texas-solution"> <para id="texas-solution-para"> Austin is the capital of Texas. </para> </solution> </exercise>

div.p: What is the capital of Texas?
Austin is the capital of Texas.

attributes.attribute:
Determines where the exercise will be placed relative to other content in the PDF version of the document.
When viewing the PDF version of the content, the exercise will be moved to the end of the chapter (default, except for an exercise contained in an example). The exercise will be displayed inline with the rest of the text (default for an exercise contained in an example).

Defines the type of exercise in order to give specialized control over numbering. Exercises of the same type are labeled in series (i.e., Exercise 1, Exercise 2...). Type can be used in conjunction with label so that exercises of each user-defined type appear with their own label. Type can be any user-defined value that reflects the purpose of the exercise.

tag.name: list
tag.description: The list tag is used to organize items into a list. Lists can be either inline or block, and the element offers a variety of different attributes that control the display and behavior of the list.

exampleexample.input: <list id="grocerylist"> <title>Grocery List</title> <item>Milk</item> <item>Eggs</item> <item>Sugar</item> </list>

<list id="write-numbers-list" list-type="enumerated" start-value="50" mark-suffix=":" item-sep="."> <title>How to Write Some Numbers</title> <item>Fifty</item> <item>Fifty-one</item> <item>Fifty-two</item> </list>

attributes.attribute:
Defines the type of list: Ordered, unordered, or bulleted by labels on each of the items.
Bullets the list of items (default). Creates a list in which each item is numbered in order. Creates a list ordered by user-specified labels.

Changes the bullet character in front of each list item. Currently, the supported values are "bullet" (default), "open-circle", "pilcrow", "rpilcrow", "asterisk", "dash", "section", literal text, and "none".
The numeric system used to display an enumerated list. Currently, the supported values are "arabic" (default), "upper-alpha", "lower-alpha", "upper-roman", and "lower-roman".
The value at which an enumerated list begins incrementing (default is "1"). Must be a positive integer, even for alphabetic or Roman numeral lists.
Adds text before each list item mark (e.g. a bullet in a bulleted list, or a number in an enumerated list). The default is nothing for all list types.
Adds text after each list item mark (e.g. a bullet in a bulleted list, or a number in an enumerated list). The default is "." for enumerated lists, and nothing for other list types.
The character used between list items. The default is ";" for inline lists and nothing for block lists.

values.value: The list will be set apart from the surrounding text (default). If the display attribute is set to "block" or is absent, then an id is required.
The list will be included in the current line of text.
The list will not be displayed.

attributes.attribute: Defines the type of list. Type can be any user-defined value that reflects the purpose of the list.

tag.name: note
tag.description: The note tag is used to add additional information that is related to text in a CNXML document, which you may want set apart from the current body of text. These notes can be points of information, cautions, warnings, and so on.

exampleexample.input: <para id="acids"> Chemistry lab was always a lot of fun. We played with a lot of chemicals such as Sulfuric and Hydrochloric acid. <note type="warning" id="dangerous"> Sulfuric and Hydrochloric Acid are very dangerous. Please handle with caution. </note> </para>

output.div:
Chemistry lab was always a lot of fun. We played with a lot of chemicals such as Sulfuric and Hydrochloric acid.
Warning:
Sulfuric and Hydrochloric Acid are very dangerous. Please handle with caution.

values.value: The note will be set apart from the surrounding text (default). If the display attribute is set to "block" or is absent, then an id is required.
The note will be included in the current line of text.
The note will not be displayed.

attributes.attribute: Defines the type of note in order to give specialized control over numbering. Notes of the same type are numbered in series (i.e., Note 1, Rule 2...). Type can be any user-defined value, but specially supported values ("note", "aside", "warning", "tip", and "important") will auto-generate a label corresponding to that type.

tag.name: problem
tag.description: The problem tag is used to present a question or task to the reader. The problem and optional solution tags appear inside the exercise tag to present a question or task and an answer, respectively, to the reader.

exampleexample.input: <exercise id="texas-exercise"> <problem id="texas-problem"> <para id="texas-problem-para"> What is the capital of Texas? </para> </problem> <solution id="texas-solution"> <para id="texas-solution-para"> Austin is the capital of Texas. </para> </solution> </exercise>

div.p: What is the capital of Texas?
Austin is the capital of Texas.

attributes.attribute: Defines the type of problem. Type can be any user-defined value that reflects the purpose of the problem.

tag.name: solution
tag.description: The solution tag is used to reveal the answer to a question presented to the reader. The problem and optional solution tags appear inside the exercise tag to present a question or task and an answer, respectively, to the reader.

exampleexample.input: <exercise id="texas-exercise"> <problem id="texas-problem"> <para id="texas-problem-para"> What is the capital of Texas? </para> </problem> <solution id="texas-solution"> <para id="texas-solution-para"> Austin is the capital of Texas. </para> </solution> </exercise>

div.p: What is the capital of Texas?
Austin is the capital of Texas.

attributes.attribute:
Determines where the solution will be placed relative to other content in the PDF version of the document. Setting the "print-placement" value on solution can be useful for overriding the value of "print-placement" set in exercise if the exercise has more than one solution.
When viewing the PDF version of the content, the exercise will be moved to the end of the chapter (default, except for an exercise contained in an example). The exercise will be displayed inline with the rest of the text (default for an exercise contained in an example).
Defines the type of solution. Type can be any user-defined value that reflects the purpose of the solution.

tag.name: content
tag.description: The content tag contains all the content information in a document module. It separates the content information from the document metadata. A document may contain only one content tag.

exampleexample.input: <content> <section id="version"> <title>Document History</title> <list id="p1"> <item> Release 0.1: Pre-release. </item> </list> </section> . . . </content>

tag.name: emphasis
tag.description: The emphasis tag is used to identify text in a CNXML document that you want or need to emphasize. Please note that this tag refers to semantic emphasis and not to any specific font, since different style sheets may render emphasized text using different fonts and styles.

exampleexample.input: <para id="emphexample"> In addition to bananas and ice cream, a proper banana split requires whipped cream, nuts, <emphasis>and</emphasis> cherries. Remember that the quality of the dessert depends on the ice cream, so do <emphasis effect="italics">not</emphasis> use a generic brand. </para>

output.p: In addition to bananas and ice cream, a proper banana split requires whipped cream, nuts, and cherries. Remember that the quality of the dessert depends on the ice cream, so do not use a generic brand.

attributes.attribute:
A style to apply to the emphasized text.
The text will be boldface (default). The text will be italicized. The text will be underlined. The text will be capitalized using small capitals. Do not apply a text effect.

tag.name: glossary
tag.description: The glossary tag is used to insert entries into a glossary that appears at the end of your CNXML document. These entries are definitions of terms in your document that you may not want to appear in the body of text. For more information see CNXML Reference Extensions.

exampleexample.input: <glossary id='module-glossary'> <definition id='quarter-def'> <term>quarter</term> <meaning> One fourth of something. </meaning> <example id='quarter-example'> <para id='glossary-para1'> "He cut the pie into quarters and gave all four people a piece." </para> </example> </definition> </glossary>

div.p: "He cut the pie into quarters and gave all four people a piece."

tag.name: meaning
tag.description: The meaning tag is used to give the meaning of the term being defined in a definition tag. Each term can have multiple definitions and therefore multiple meaning tags.

exampleexample.input: <definition id='quardef'> <term>quarter</term> <meaning id="meaning-part"> One fourth of something. </meaning> <example id='defex1'> <para id='parex1'> "He cut the pie into quarters and gave all four people a piece." </para> </example> <meaning id="meaning-money"> 25 cents, a quarter of a dollar. </meaning> <seealso> <term>dollar</term> <term>penny</term> </seealso> </definition>

div.p: "He cut the pie into quarters and gave all four people a piece."

dd.div:
2.
25 cents, a quarter of a dollar.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The param tag is used to pass parameters to the various types of media elements.

exampleexample.input: <media id="chromatic-snd" display="block" alt="A chromatic scale performed on the clarinet by Michael Lawrence"> <audio mime-type="audio/x-wav" src="chromatic_slurred.wav"> <param name="title" value="Chromatic Scale" /> </audio> </media>

tag.note: Compare this output to the output of an audio tag without a title param.

attributes.attribute: The attribute name of the parameter.
The value for the parameter.

children.note: The param tag is an empty tag and does not contain any children.

tag.name: proof
tag.description: The proof tag is used to present the proof or explanation of a rule. The statement and proof tags appear inside the rule tag to state a rule and to present the proof of the rule.

exampleexample.input: <rule id="py-rule" type="theorem"> <title>Pythagorean Theorem</title> <statement id="py-statement"> <para id="ruleexp1"> On a right triangle, the sum of the squares of the sides equals the square of the hypotenuse. </para> </statement> <proof id="py-proof"> <para id="ruleexp2"> <link url="http://en.wikipedia.org /wiki/Pythagorean_theorem#Proofs" window="new"> Click here to see a few proofs. </link> </para> </proof> </rule>

div.p: On a right triangle, the sum of the squares of the sides equals the square of the hypotenuse.

p.a: Click here to see a few proofs.

attributes.attribute: Defines the type of proof. Type can be any user-defined value that reflects the purpose of the proof.

tag.name: rule
tag.description: The rule tag defines any type of "rule," such as a theorem, axiom, lemma, rule of thumb, etc., that is presented as a statement optionally accompanied by a proof or examples. This tag is especially useful for mathematical texts.

exampleexample.input: <rule type='theorem' id='pythag-rule'> <title>Pythagorean Theorem</title> <statement id='pythag-statement'> <para id='pythag-para1'> On a right triangle, the sum of the squares of the sides equals the square of the hypotenuse. </para> </statement> <proof id='pythag-proof'> <para id='pythag-para2'> Your favorite proof goes here. </para> </proof> <example id="pythag-example"> <para id='pythag-para3'> Take a right triangle whose sides are of length 3, 4, and 5. In this case the sum of the square of the two shorter sides is 9+16=25. The square of the hypotenuse is 25. So the theorem holds. </para> </example> </rule>

div.p: On a right triangle, the sum of the squares of the sides equals the square of the hypotenuse.
Your favorite proof goes here.
Take a right triangle whose sides are of length 3, 4, and 5. In this case the sum of the square of the two shorter sides is 9+16=25. The square of the hypotenuse is 25. So the theorem holds.

attributes.attribute: Defines the type of rule in order to give specialized control over numbering. Rules of the same type are numbered in series (i.e., Rule 1, Rule 2...). Type can be any user-defined value, but specially supported values ("rule", "theorem", "lemma", "corollary", "law", and "proposition") will auto-generate a label corresponding to that type.

children.note: First, rule may contain an optional label tag. Next, it may contain an optional title tag. Next, it must contain one or more statement tags. Finally, rule may contain zero or more proof tags and zero or more example tags in any order.

tag.name: section
tag.description: The section tag divides a document into sections, topics, subsections, or subtopics.

exampleexample.input: <section id="res"> <title>Resistor</title> <para id="para2"> . . . </para> </section> <section id="cap"> <title>Capacitor</title> <para id="para3"> . . . </para> </section> <section id="ind"> <title>Inductor</title> <para id="para4"> . . . </para> </section>

attributes.attribute: Defines the type of section. Type can be any user-defined value that reflects the purpose of the section.

tag.name: seealso
tag.description: The seealso tag is used to list related terms that you believe are beneficial to the reader of the document.

exampleexample.input: <definition id='quarter-def'> <term>quarter</term> <meaning id="meaning-money"> 25 cents; a quarter of a dollar. </meaning> <seealso> <term>dollar</term> <term>penny</term> </seealso> </definition>

dd.div: 25 cents; a quarter of a dollar.

attributes.attribute: The type of "see also" item referenced. Type can be any user-defined value that reflects the purpose of the element.

tagref.note: only one seealso tag may appear inside a definition tag

tag.name: statement
tag.description: The statement tag is used inside the rule tag to write a definition or description of the rule in which it is placed.

exampleexample.input: <rule type='theorem' id='pythag-rule'> <title>Pythagorean Theorem</title> <statement id='pythag-statement'> <para id='pythag-para1'> On a right triangle, the sum of the squares of the sides equals the square of the hypotenuse. </para> </statement> </rule>

div.p: On a right triangle, the sum of the squares of the sides equals the square of the hypotenuse.

attributes.attribute: Defines the type of statement. Type can be any user-defined value that reflects the purpose of the statement.

tag.name: cite-title
tag.description: The cite-title tag is used to explicitly define the title of a citation. The cite element contains the full text of the citation, whereas the cite-title only contains the title of the citation.

exampleexample.input: <cite> <cite-title>A Tale of Two Cities</cite-title> by Charles Dickens </cite> is a classic novel.

output.p:
A Tale of Two Cities by Charles Dickens
is a classic novel.

exampleexample.input: <para id="techdoc-para"> You can read my latest article, <cite-title pub-type="article">Writing Technical Documentation</cite-title> in this month's <cite-title pub-type="booklet">Help Files Quarterly</cite-title>. </para>

output.p:
You can read my latest article,
"Writing Technical Documentation" in this month's
Help Files Quarterly.

attributes.attribute: The type of publication cited. May be any of the following: "article", "book", "booklet", "conference", "inbook", "incollection", "inproceedings", "mastersthesis", "manual", "misc", "phdthesis", "proceedings", "techreport", "unpublished".

tag.name: definition
tag.description: The definition tag is used to define a word or a term.

exampleexample.input: <definition id='quarter-def'> <term>quarter</term> <meaning id="meaning-part"> One fourth of something. </meaning> <example id='quarter-ex-1'> <para id='quarter-para-1'> "He cut the pie into quarters and gave all four people a piece." </para> </example> <meaning id="meaning-money"> 25 cents; a quarter of a dollar. </meaning> <seealso> <term>dollar</term> <term>penny</term> </seealso> </definition>

div.p: "He cut the pie into quarters and gave all four people a piece."

dd.div:
2.
25 cents; a quarter of a dollar.

attributes.attribute: Defines the type of definition in order to give specialized control over numbering. Definitions of the same type are numbered in series (i.e., Definition 1, Definition 2...). Type can be used in conjunction with label so that definitions of each user-defined type appear with their own label. Type can be any user-defined value that reflects the purpose of the definition.

children.note: First, definition may contain an optional label tag. Next, it must contain a single term tag. Then, it must contain one or more meaning tags, followed in turn by any optional example tags associated with that meaning. Finally, definition may contain an optional seealso tag.

tag.name: equation
tag.description:
The equation tag is used to set off equations in CNXML documents by using the Math Mark-up Language (MathML) or embedded media to display math.
Note:
You are strongly encouraged to use equation with Content MathML tags when you want to display mathematical formulas or equations in your CNXML document.

exampleexample.input: <equation id="simpleaddmathml"> <title>Addition using MathML</title> <m:math> <m:apply> <m:eq/> <m:apply> <m:plus/> <m:cn>1</m:cn> <m:cn>2</m:cn> </m:apply> <m:cn>3</m:cn> </m:apply> </m:math> </equation>
<equation id="simpleaddplain"> <title>Addition without MathML</title> 1 + 2 = 3 </equation>

attributes.attribute: Defines the type of equation in order to give specialized control over numbering. Equations of the same type are numbered in series (i.e., Equation (1), Equation (2)...). Type can be used in conjunction with label so that equations of each user-defined type appear with their own label. Type can be any user-defined value that reflects the purpose of the equation.

children.note: First, equation may contain an optional label tag. Next, it may contain an optional title tag. Finally, equation must contain either media, MathML, or Unicode Text.

tag.name: tgroup
tag.description: The tgroup tag identifies a new portion of a table.

exampleexample.input: Report card Course Semester Grade Average: 85.5% Biology 1 86% 2 91% English 1 87% 2 78%

table.summary: The first column lists each course. Each row in the second column delineates a semester. The corresponding row in the third column shows that semester's grade. The footer tallies the student's average.

th.style: border-top: 0 none ! important; border-left: 0 none ! important; border-right: 1px solid; border-bottom: 1px solid; text-align: left ! important;

attributes.attribute: Number of columns in the tgroup. Must be a positive integer.

Sets whether the internal column rulings are displayed or not (ignored for the rightmost column of the table, where the "frame" value applies).
Do not display column rulings. Display column rulings.
Default comes from the "colsep" value in table, if any, otherwise it is "1".

Sets whether the internal row rulings are displayed or not (ignored for the last row of the table, where the "frame" value applies).
Do not display row rulings. Display row rulings.
Default comes from the "rowsep" value in table, if any. Otherwise it is "1".

Sets how the text will be aligned.
Left aligned (default). Right aligned. Center aligned. Right and left aligned. Aligns to the leftmost occurrence of the value of the char attribute.
The character used in the align attribute. Default is no aligning character.
The pertcentage of the column width to the left of the char used in the align attribute. Default is "50".

tag.name: colspec
tag.description: The colspec tag specifies a column of a table or entrytbl

exampleexample.input: Dichotomies Extroverted Introverted Sensing iNtuition Thinking Feeling Judging Perceiving

table.summary: Chart of Myers-Briggs types, with each column representing opposite ends of the four dichotomies.

th.style: border-top: 0 none ! important; border-left: 0 none ! important; border-right: 0 none ! important; border-bottom: 1px solid; text-align: center ! important;

td.style: border-top: 0 none ! important; border-left: 0 none ! important; border-right: 1px solid; border-bottom: 1px solid; text-align: center ! important;

border: 0 none ! important; text-align: center ! important;

attributes.attribute: Number of the column. Must be a positive integer.
Name of the column (for reference by entry and entrytbl).

The width of the column.
"5*" means five times the proportion. "3pt" means 3 points.
Default is "1*".

Sets whether the internal column rulings are displayed or not (ignored for the rightmost column of a table, where the "frame" value applies, and for the rightmost column of an entrytbl, where the entrytbl's "colsep" value applies).
Do not display column rulings. Display column rulings.
Default is implied from the nearest ancestor with a declared or implied "colsep" value (entrytbl, if any, or tgroup).

Sets whether the internal row rulings are displayed or not (ignored for the last row of the table, where the "frame" value applies, and for the last row of an entrytbl, where the entrytbl's "rowsep" value applies).
Do not display row rulings. Display row rulings.
Default is implied from the nearest ancestor with a declared or implied "rowsep" value (entrytbl, if any, or tgroup).

Sets how the text will be aligned.
Left aligned. Right aligned. Center aligned. Right and left aligned. Aligns to the leftmost occurrence of the value of the char attribute.
The character used in the align attribute. Default is implied from the nearest ancestor with a declared of implied "char" value (entrytbl, if any, or tgroup).

The pertcentage of the column width to the left of the char used in the align attribute. Default is implied from the nearest ancestor with a declared of implied "charoff" value (entrytbl, if any, or tgroup).

children.note: The colspec tag is an empty tag and does not contain any children.

tag.name: spanspec
tag.description: The spanspec tag identifies a horizontal span of columns and associated attributes that can subsequently be referenced by its spanname for repeated use in entry or entrytbl in different rows.

exampleexample.input: Dichotomies Extroverted Introverted Sensing iNtuition Thinking Feeling Judging Perceiving

table.summary: Chart of Myers-Briggs types, with each column representing opposite ends of the four dichotomies.

attributes.attribute: Name of the furthest left column in the span. Must correspond to the value of a "colname" attribute in a colspec.
Name of the furthest right column in the span. Must correspond to the value of a "colname" attribute in a colspec.
Name for the horizontal span (for reference by entry and entrytbl).

Sets whether the internal column rulings are displayed or not (ignored for the rightmost column of a table, where the "frame" value applies, and for the rightmost column of an entrytbl, where the entrytbl's "colsep" value applies).
Do not display column rulings. Display column rulings.
Default is implied from the colspec of the column specified by the "namest" attribute.

Sets whether the internal row rulings are displayed or not (ignored for the last row of the table, where the "frame" value applies, and for the last row of an entrytbl, where the entrytbl's "rowsep" value applies).
Do not display row rulings. Display row rulings.
Default is implied from the colspec of the column specified by the "namest" attribute.

Sets how the text will be aligned.
Left aligned. Right aligned. Center aligned (default). Right and left aligned. Aligns to the leftmost occurrence of the value of the char attribute.
The character used in the align attribute. Default is implied from the colspec of the column specified by the "namest" attribute.
The pertcentage of the column width to the left of the char used in the align attribute. Default is implied from the colspec of the column specified by the "namest" attribute.

children.note: The spanspec tag is an empty tag and does not contain any children.

tag.name: row
tag.description: The row tag identifies the row of information in a thead, tbody, or tfoot.

tag.name: entrytbl

attributes.attribute:
How many more rows the entry will span vertically.
The entry will span no rows (default).
The number of rows in the span after the current one.
Name referring to the "colname" attribute in the corresponding colspec for the entry's column.
Name of horizontal spanning of columns. Must correspond to the value of a "spanname" attribute in the spanspec of an ancestor entrytbl or tgroup.
Name of the furthest left column in a horizontal spanning of columns. Must correspond to the value of a "colname" attribute in the colspec of an ancestor entrytbl or tgroup.
Name of the furthest right column in a horizontal spanning of columns. Must correspond to the value of a "colname" attribute in the colspec of an ancestor entrytbl or tgroup.

Sets whether the internal column rulings are displayed or not (ignored for the rightmost column of a table, where the "frame" value applies, and for the rightmost column of an entrytbl, where the entrytbl's "colsep" value applies).
Do not display column rulings. Display column rulings.
Default is implied from the nearest ancestor with a declared or implied "colsep" value (spanspec specified by the "spanname" attribute, colspec, entrytbl, or tgroup).

Sets whether the internal row rulings are displayed or not (ignored for the last row of the table, where the "frame" value applies, and for the last row of an entrytbl, where the entrytbl's "rowsep" value applies).
Do not display row rulings. Display row rulings.
Default is implied from the nearest ancestor with a declared or implied "rowsep" value (row, spanspec specified by the "spanname" attribute, colspec, entrytbl, or tgroup).

Sets how the text will be aligned.
Left aligned. Right aligned. Center aligned. Right and left aligned. Aligns to the leftmost occurrence of the value of the char attribute.

Vertical position of the text within the entry.
Default is implied from the nearest ancestor with a declared or implied "valign" value (row).

tag.name: para
tag.description: The para tag contains a paragraph of text. The text may contain other CNXML elements and markup.

exampleexample.input: <para id="para1"> Prince Andrei was on duty that day and in constant attendance on the Commander in Chief. </para> <para id="para2"> At six o'clock in the evening Kutuzov went to the Emperor's headquarters, and after remaining but a short time with him, went to the Grand Marshal of the Court, Count Tolstoy. </para>

output.p: Prince Andrei was on duty that day and in constant attendance on the Commander in Chief.
At six o'clock in the evening Kutuzov went to the Emperor's headquarters, and after remaining but a short time with him, went to the Grand Marshal of the Court, Count Tolstoy.

tag.name: item
tag.description: The item tag is used to specify an item of a list. It appears only as the child of list tags.

exampleexample.input: <list id='forces-list'> <title>Four fundamental forces</title> <item>Electromagnetism</item> <item>Gravity</item> <item>Strong nuclear force</item> <item>Weak nuclear force</item> </list>

tag.name: quote
tag.description: The quote tag is used to insert a quotation, either inline or set apart in a block.

exampleexample.input: <para id="quoteexample"> <title> To be or not to be...</title> <quote id="hamlet-quote" url='http://tinyurl.com/bu393'> "To be, or not to be: that is the question: Whether 'tis nobler in the mind to suffer The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune, Or to take arms against a sea of troubles, And by opposing end them?"</quote> </para>

h3.strong: To be or not to be...

div.blockquote: "To be, or not to be: that is the question: Whether 'tis nobler in the mind to suffer The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune, Or to take arms against a sea of troubles, And by opposing end them?" [source]

exampleexample.input: <para id="famous-quote"> One of Shakespeare's most famous quotes is <quote display="inline">To be or not to be, that is the question.</quote> </para>

output.p: One of Shakespeare's most famous quotes is "To be or not to be, that is the question."

values.value: The quote will be set apart from the surrounding text (default). If the display attribute is set to "block" or is absent, then an id is required.
The quote will be included in the current line of text and will be surrounded by quotation marks.
The quote will not be displayed.

linkingattributes.linkingattributesdescription: used to link to a quote's source

attributes.attribute: The type of quote. Can be any user-defined value. You decide the value of "type". The value should reflect the purpose of the quote.

tag.name: foreign
tag.description: The foreign tag is used to identify any text that is a foreign word or phrase.

exampleexample.input: <para id="spanish-hello"> In Spanish speaking countries you may hear people say <foreign>hola amigo</foreign>, which means 'hello friend'. </para>

output.p: In Spanish speaking countries you may hear people say hola amigo, which means 'hello friend'.

linkingattributes.linkingattributesdescription: used to link to a translation or other source

tag.name: cite
tag.description: The cite tag is used to create citations to other materials. It should be used in in conjunction with the cite-title element to set the title apart from the rest of the citation.

exampleexample.input: <cite> <cite-title>A Tale of Two Cities</cite-title> by Charles Dickens </cite> is a classic novel.

output.p:
A Tale of Two Cities by Charles Dickens
is a classic novel.

exampleexample.input: <para id="citeexample2"> This article was taken from <cite window="new" url="http://www.cnn.com"> CNN.com </cite>. </para>

output.p: This article was taken from CNN.com [link].

linkingattributes.linkingattributesdescription: used to link to a citation's source

tag.name: term
tag.description: The term tag is used to mark a word or phrase being defined. It can be used inside a definition tag or in regular text. Words marked with the term tag appear in the index section of a collection PDF.

exampleexample.input: <para id='square-term'> A <term>square</term> is a rectangle with sides of equal length. </para>

output.p: A square is a rectangle with sides of equal length.

exampleexample.input: <para id='square-wave-term'> A <term document="m0004" target-id="sq" window="new">square wave</term> is a periodic signal that alternates instantly between two amplitudes. </para>

output.p: A square wave is a periodic signal that alternates instantly between two amplitudes.

linkingattributes.linkingattributesdescription: used to link to a term's source

tag.name: link
tag.description: The link tag is used to insert links to external resources.

exampleexample.input: <para id="linkexample"> There are many ways to grill <link document="m10275" version="2.1">a good steak</link>. My favorite can be found <link url="http://en.wikibooks.org/" window="new">on Wikibooks</link>. </para>

output.p: There are many ways to grill a good steak. My favorite can be found on Wikibooks.

tag.div: Note: Links must provide a target, so one of the following attributes must be defined: "url", "document", "target-id", "resource", or "version".

Note: Starting with version 0.6, the CNXML language does not permit URLs that contain ampersand (&) characters (i.e., http://cnx.org/example?i=1&p=2). Check all URLs and replace any ampersands with the entity reference "&". More information can be found on the W3C's page.

values.value: Sets link strength to 1 (the weakest)
Sets link strength to 2 (medium strength)
Sets link strength to 3 (the strongest)

tag.name: table
tag.description: The table tag marks beginning of a table. CNXML uses the CALS Table Model for including tables in CNXML documents. For a more complete description of the CALS Table consult the CALS Table Model Spec.

exampleexample.input: Report card Course Semester Grade Average: 85.5% Biology 1 86% 2 91% English 1 87% 2 78%

attributes.attribute: The table summary should describe the main purpose of the table and explain its overall structure. The contents of the summary will not show on the screen, but can be used to help visually impaired readers that are listening to the content understand the table. Learn more.

Position of lines drawn around table.
All sides of the table (default). Left and right. Above the first row. After the last row. Top and bottom. None of the above.

Sets whether the internal column rulings are displayed or not (ignored for the rightmost column of the table, where the "frame" value applies).
Do not display column rulings. Display column rulings.
Default is "1".

Sets whether the internal row rulings are displayed or not (ignored for the last row of the table, where the "frame" value applies).
Do not display column rulings. Display column rulings.
Default is "1".

Determines the available width of the table.
Maximum width of the table is the galley width (default). The width of the table is the entire width of the page.

tag.name: subfigure
tag.description: The subfigure tag is used when you want to include multiple figures, tables, or blocks of code within a single figure tag. You should use the subfigure tag only if the subfigures are related and you want to display them together. The subfigure tag is similar to the figure tag, except that it cannot contain another subfigure tag.

img.alt: A dog sitting on a bed

attributes.attribute: Defines the type of subfigure in order to give specialized control over numbering. Subfigures of the same type are numbered in series (i.e., Figure 1(a), Figure 1(b)...). Type can be used in conjunction with label so that subfigures of each user-defined type appear with their own label. Type can be any user-defined value that reflects the purpose of the subfigure.

children.note:
First, subfigure may contain an optional label tag, followed by an optional title tag. Next, it must contain:
One media tag, - OR -
One table tag, - OR -
One code tag.
Finally, figure may contain an optional caption tag.

tag.name: figure
tag.description: The figure tag is used to provide the structure for inserting a figure into a CNXML document. A figure may contain an image, multimedia object, or caption tag.

table.caption: Figure 1: Notice how cute the dog is just sitting there.

img.alt: A dog sitting on a bed

attributes.attribute:
Allows you to determine which way subfigure elements are arranged. Has no effect if the figure has no subfigure children.
Subfigures appear side by side (default).
Subfigures appear one on top of the other.

Defines the type of figure in order to give specialized control over numbering. Figures of the same type are numbered in series (i.e., Figure 1, Figure 2...). Type can be used in conjunction with label so that figures of each user-defined type appear with their own label. Type can be any user-defined value that reflects the purpose of the figure.

children.note:
First, figure may contain an optional label tag, followed by an optional title tag. Next, it must contain:
Two or more subfigure tags, - OR -
One media tag, - OR -
One table tag, - OR -
One code tag.
Finally, figure may contain an optional caption tag.

tag.name: sub
tag.description: The sub tag is used to display subscript text. It should not be used to markup mathematical expressions; instead, use Content MathML to create expressions with subscripts.

exampleexample.input: <para id="directionse"> The northern tip of the lake, or Tip<sub>North</sub>, is 10 miles south of the campsite. </para>

output.p: The northern tip of the lake, or TipNorth, is 10 miles south of the campsite.

tag.name: sup
tag.description: The sup tag is used to display superscript text. It should not be used to markup mathematical exponents; instead, use Content MathML to create exponents and math with superscripts.

exampleexample.input: <para id="armstrong"> Neil Armstrong was the 1<sup>st</sup> man on the moon. </para>

output.p: Neil Armstrong was the 1st man on the moon.

tag.name: footnote
tag.description: The footnote tag is used to generate a footnote on selected text.

exampleexample.input: <para id="example-paragraph"> Many people may not know that cheesecake is tart, not a cake. <footnote id="example-footnote"> Alan Davidson, Oxford Companion to Food, s.v. cheesecake: "Cheesecake, not a cake in the ordinary sense, is really a kind of tart." </footnote> </para>

output.p: Many people may not know that cheesecake is tart, not a cake. 1

ol.li: Alan Davidson, Oxford Companion to Food, s.v. cheesecake: "Cheesecake, not a cake in the ordinary sense, is really a kind of tart."

tag.name: image
tag.description: The image tag is used to place image files, such as JPG, GIF, and PNG, into modules. Any image file with a valid MIME type can be included on the page.

exampleexample.input: <media id="greyhound" alt="A greyhound relaxing on a bed."> <image mime-type="image/jpeg" src="image1.jpg" /> </media>

img.alt: A greyhound relaxing on a bed.

exampleexample.input: <media id="greyhound" alt="A greyhound relaxing on a bed."> <image mime-type="image/jpeg" src="image1.jpg" /> <image mime-type="application/postscript" src="image1.eps" for="pdf"/> </media>

img.alt: A greyhound relaxing on a bed.

exampleexample.p: This example demonstrates the use of the for attribute to specify an alternate image for the PDF version of the module. The Web-ready JPEG image, here used as the default option, will be displayed when viewing the module online and the second image, a higher-resolution EPS file, will be used for the PDF version.

attributes.attribute:
The location of the image file. It must be a URL value. If the image is stored alongside the module, the file name itself is sufficient (e.g. "img.jpg").
Note: Starting with version 0.6, the CNXML language does not permit URLs that contain ampersand (&) characters (i.e., http://cnx.org/example?i=1&p=2). Check all object src URLs and replace any ampersands with the entity reference "&". More information can be found on the W3C's page.

The MIME type of the image. This requried value tells each visitor's browser what sort of information is contained in the image. The most commonly used image files and their corresponding MIME types are: "image/jpeg" (for .jpg images), "image/gif" (for .gif images), and "image/png" (for .png images). A list of common Internet media MIME types can be found here.

Specifies whether this object should be displayed in the online or PDF version of the content, or be used as the default media object. If there is no default media object present, then the <media> element will only be displayed for the version(s) specified.
This element is used for both PDF and online versions unless another, version-specific element is present (default). This element is used only for the PDF version of the content. This element is used only for the online version of the content.
The height of the image in pixels. Must be a nonnegative integer.
The width of the image in pixels. Must be a nonnegative integer.

The width of the image for the PDF version of the module. Must be specified as a number plus a unit of width (e.g., "5in"). Supported units include "in" (inches), "cm" (centimeters), "pt" (points) and others. There is no corresponding "print-height" attribute. The height of the image in PDF will be determined proportionally.
The URL of an image file to be used as a thumbnail for the larger image. The thumbnail file will automatically link to the larger image file set in the "src" attribute.

The URL of a file containing a long description of the image. Not all readers will be able to see your included media in their browser, either due to blindness, low-vision, or an environment that doesn't support the media. Some images are too complex to describe fully in a few words using the "alt" attribute, however. For images like charts and graphs that are important for understanding the material, use "longdesc" to point to a Web file that contains a full explanation of the image.

tag.name: audio
tag.description: The audio tag is used to place audio files, such as MP3, WAV, and AIFF, into modules. Any audio file with a valid MIME type can be included on the page.

exampleexample.input: <media id="chromatic-snd" display="block" alt="A chromatic scale performed on the clarinet by Michael Lawrence"> <audio mime-type="audio/x-wav" src="chromatic_slurred.wav" /> </media>

attributes.attribute:
The location of the audio file. It must be a URL value. If the audio is stored alongside the module, the file name itself can be used (e.g. "clip.mp3").
Note: Starting with version 0.6, the CNXML language does not permit URLs that contain ampersand (&) characters (i.e., http://cnx.org/example?i=1&p=2). Check all object src URLs and replace any ampersands with the entity reference "&". More information can be found on the W3C's page.
The MIME type of the audio. This requried value tells each visitor's browser what sort of information is contained in the audio file. A list of common Internet media MIME types can be found here.

Specifies whether this object should be displayed in the online or PDF version of the content, or be used as the default media object. If there is no default object present, then the <media> element will only be displayed for the version(s) specified.
This element is used for both PDF and online versions unless another, version-specific element is present (default). This element is used only for the PDF version of the content. This element is used only for the online version of the content.
A message to display while the audio data is loading.

Toggles the audio file on or off autoplay mode.
Plays the audio file automatically. Does not play the audio file automatically.

Toggles audio file looping.
Loops the audio. Does not loop the audio (default).

Toggles a timeline controller for the audio file.
Displays a timeline controller. Does display a timeline controller.
Sets the volume of the audio file. Must be an integer from 1 to 100 (default is "50").
The URL of a file containing a long description of the audio.

tag.name: video
tag.description: The video tag is used to place video files, such as MPEG, AVI, and MOV, into modules. Any video file with a valid MIME type can be included on the page.

exampleexample.input: <media id="building-on-past" alt="Building on the past."> <video mime-type="video/mpeg" src="Building_on_the_Past.mpg" autoplay="false" width="320" height="260" /> </media>

attributes.attribute:
The location of the video file. It must be a URL value. If the video is stored alongside the module, the file name itself can be used (e.g. "clip.mp3").
Note: Starting with version 0.6, the CNXML language does not permit URLs that contain ampersand (&) characters (i.e., http://cnx.org/example?i=1&p=2). Check all object src URLs and replace any ampersands with the entity reference "&". More information can be found on the W3C's page.
The MIME type of the video. This requried value tells each visitor's browser what sort of information is contained in the video file. A list of common Internet media MIME types can be found here.

Specifies whether this object should be displayed in the online or PDF version of the content, or be used as the default media object. If there is no default media object present, then the <media> element will only be displayed for the version(s) specified.
This element is used for both PDF and online versions unless another, version-specific element is present (default). This element is used only for the PDF version of the content. This element is used only for the online version of the content.
A message to display while the video data is loading.

Toggles the video file on or off autoplay mode.
Plays the video file automatically. Does not play the video file automatically.

Toggles video file looping.
Loops the video. Does not loop the video (default).

Toggles a timeline controller for the video file.
Displays a timeline controller. Does not display a timeline controller.
Sets the volume of the video file. Default is any integer from 1 to 100 (default is "50").
The height of the video in pixels.
The width of the video in pixels.

The URL of a file containing a long description of the video. Not all readers will be able to see your included media in their browser, either due to blindness, low-vision, or an environment that doesn't support the media. Some videos are too complex to describe fully in a few words using the "alt" attribute, however. For videos that are important for understanding the material, use "longdesc" to point to a Web file that contains a full explanation of the video.

tag.name: java-applet
tag.description: The java-applet tag is used to place Java applets into modules.

exampleexample.input: <media id="complex-sinusoid" alt="A Complex Sinusoid"> <java-applet mime-type="application/x-java-applet" code="PhasorDemo.class" width="400" height="500" /> </media>

attributes.attribute: This attribute specifies either the name of the class file that contains the applet's compiled applet subclass or the path to get the class, including the class file itself.

The MIME type of the Java object, e.g., "application/x-java-applet". This requried value tells each visitor's browser what sort of information is contained in the object. A list of common Internet media MIME types can be found here.

Specifies whether this object should be displayed in the online or PDF version of the content, or be used as the default media object. If there is no default object present, then the <media> element will only be displayed for the version(s) specified.
This element is used for both PDF and online versions unless another, version-specific element is present (default). This element is used only for the PDF version of the content. This element is used only for the online version of the content.
A URI specifying the where the applet's files are located. If this attribute is not set, the browser will by default assume the applet's files are located in the current directory.
A comma-separated list of URIs for archives containing classes and other resources that will be "preloaded".
This attribute specifies a name for the applet instance, which makes it possible for applets on the same page to find (and communicate with) each other.

The location of the Java object file. It must be a URL value. If the Java object is stored alongside the module, the file name itself can be used.
Note: Starting with version 0.6, the CNXML language does not permit URLs that contain ampersand (&) characters (i.e., http://cnx.org/example?i=1&p=2). Check all object src URLs and replace any ampersands with the entity reference "&". More information can be found on the W3C's page.
The height of the Java applet in pixels.
The width of the Java applet in pixels.

The URL of a file containing a long description of the applet. Not all readers will be able to see your included media in their browser, either due to blindness, low-vision, or an environment that doesn't support the media. Some applets are too complex to describe fully in a few words using the "alt" attribute, however. For applets that are important for understanding the material, use "longdesc" to point to a Web file that contains a full explanation of the applet.

tag.name: download
tag.description: The download tag is used to insert a link to a file download. The file can be located in the module directory itself, or another location on the Web.

exampleexample.input: <media id="course-syl" alt="Business Ethics Course Syllabus"> <download mime-type="application/msword" src="Business Ethics Spring 2007.doc"/> </media>

attributes.attribute:
The location of the file. It must be a URL value. If the file is stored alongside the module, the file name itself can be used (e.g. "report.doc").
Note: Starting with version 0.6, the CNXML language does not permit URLs that contain ampersand (&) characters (i.e., http://cnx.org/example?i=1&p=2). Check all object src URLs and replace any ampersands with the entity reference "&". More information can be found on the W3C's page.
The MIME type of the file. This requried value tells each visitor's browser what sort of information is contained in the file. A list of common Internet media MIME types can be found here.

Specifies whether this object should be displayed in the online or PDF version of the content, or be used as the default media object. If there is no default object present, then the <media> element will only be displayed for the version(s) specified.
This element is used for both PDF and online versions unless another, version-specific element is present (default). This element is used only for the PDF version of the content. This element is used only for the online version of the content.

The URL of a file containing a long description of the download. Not all readers will be able to see your included media in their browser, either due to blindness, low-vision, or an environment that doesn't support the media. Some media are too complex to describe fully in a few words using the "alt" attribute, however. For media like charts and graphs that are important for understanding the material, use "longdesc" to point to a Web file that contains a full explanation of the media.

tag.name: media
tag.description:
The media tag is used to insert media objects into a CNXML document. The media objects can be images, applets, movies, sounds, or any object with a valid MIME type.
Note: Starting with version 0.6, the CNXML language does not permit URLs that contain ampersand (&) characters (i.e., http://cnx.org/example?i=1&p=2). Check all media src URLs and replace any ampersands with the entity reference "&". More information can be found on the W3C's page.

exampleexample.input:
<media id="dog_on_couch" alt="A dog sitting on a couch.">
<image mime-type="image/jpeg" src="image1.jpg" />
</media>

img.alt: A dog sitting on a couch

attributes.attribute: "Alt" text is used by browsers and other tools to make the content of images available to all users, including visually impaired users with screen readers. It is a text representation of the meaning of an image. Remember, "alt" text replaces an image; it does not describe it.

values.value: The media will be set apart from the surrounding text.
The media will be included in the current line of text.
The media will not be displayed.

attributes.attribute: The URL of a file containing a long description of the media. Not all readers will be able to see your included media in their browser, either due to blindness, low-vision, or an environment that doesn't support the media. Some media are too complex to describe fully in a few words using the "alt" attribute, however. For media like charts and graphs that are important for understanding the material, use "longdesc" to point to a Web file that contains a full explanation of the media.

tag.name: flash
tag.description: The flash tag is used to insert Flash multimedia into a CNXML document. The multimedia can be images, SWFs, FLVs, or any object with a valid Flash MIME type.

exampleexample.input: <media id="flash-example" alt="Dancing Connexions"> <flash mime-type="application/x-shockwave-flash" src="flash2.swf" width="282" height="108"/> </media>

<media id="curved-line" alt="Dancing Connexions"> <flash mime-type="application/x-shockwave-flash" src="flash2.swf" width="282" height="108"/> <image mime-type="image/png" src="dancing-cnx-still.png" print-width="4in" for="pdf"/> </media>
exampleexample.p: This example demonstrates using alternate media for the PDF version of the module. Flash elements cannot be inserted into PDF files. In this case, the Web-ready Flash file will be displayed when viewing the module online and the second element, a still shot from the animation, will be used for the PDF version.

attributes.attribute:
The location of the Flash file. It must be a URL value. If the Flash file is stored alongside the module, the file name itself can be used (e.g. "file.flv").
Note: Starting with version 0.6, the CNXML language does not permit URLs that contain ampersand (&) characters (i.e., http://cnx.org/example?i=1&p=2). Check all object src URLs and replace any ampersands with the entity reference "&". More information can be found on the W3C's page.

The MIME type of the Flash file, e.g., "application/x-shockwave-flash" or "video/x-flv". This requried value tells each visitor's browser what sort of information is contained in the Flash file. A list of common Internet media MIME types can be found here.

Specifies whether this object should be displayed in the online or PDF version of the content, or be used as the default media object. If there is no default media object present, then the <media> element will only be displayed for the version(s) specified.
This element is used for both PDF and online versions unless another, version-specific element is present (default). This element is used only for the PDF version of the content. This element is used only for the online version of the content.

values.value: Creates a seperate rectangular window.
Makes the movie hide everything on the page behind it.
Makes the background of the HTML page shows through all transparent portions of the movie.

attributes.attribute:
Sets the quality of the Flash file.
Sets the quality of the Flash file to low. Automatically sets the quality of the Flash file to the lowest setting where playback speed does not suffer too much but preserves quality. Automatically sets the quality of the Flash file to the highest setting where quality does not suffer too much. Sets the quality of the Flash file to medium. Sets the quality of the Flash file to high.

Toggles video file looping.
Loops the video. Does not loop the video (default).

Sets the scale for the Flash file.
Uses the default scaling of the Flash file (default). Scales the movie to fill the specified area, without distortion but possibly with some cropping. Makes the entire movie visible in the specified area without trying to preserve the original aspect ratio.
Sets the background color of the Flash file. Takes a 6-character hexadecimal code (a-f, A-F, 0-9).
Used to pass parameters into the Flash media's FlashVars property.
Sets the height of the Flash media in pixels.
Sets the width of the Flash media in pixels.

The URL of a file containing a long description of the Flash file. Not all readers will be able to see your included media in their browser, either due to blindness, low-vision, or an environment that doesn't support the media. Some media are too complex to describe fully in a few words using the "alt" attribute, however. For media like charts and graphs that are important for understanding the material, use "longdesc" to point to a Web file that contains a full explanation of the media.

tag.name: labview
tag.description: The labview tag is used to place LabVIEW files (*.vi) into modules.

exampleexample.input: <media id="dist-vi" display="block" alt="Probability distrubutions"> <labview mime-type="application/x-labview-vi" viname="common_distributions.viinfo" version="7.0" src="Common_Distributions.vi" /> </media>

attributes.attribute:
The location of the LabVIEW file. It must be a URL value. If the LabVIEW file is stored alongside the module, the file name itself can be used (e.g. "file.vi").
Note: Starting with version 0.6, the CNXML language does not permit URLs that contain ampersand (&) characters (i.e., http://cnx.org/example?i=1&p=2). Check all object src URLs and replace any ampersands with the entity reference "&". More information can be found on the W3C's page.
Sets the path to the executable LabVIEW file.

values.value: Specifies that the version of the LabVIEW file is 7.0.
Specifies that the version of the LabVIEW file is 8.0.
Specifies that the version of the LabVIEW file is 8.2.

attributes.attribute: The MIME type of the LabVIEW file, e.g., "application/x-labview-vi". This requried value tells each visitor's browser what sort of information is contained in the LabVIEW file. A list of common Internet media MIME types can be found here.

Specifies whether this object should be displayed in the online or PDF version of the content, or be used as the default media object. If there is no default media object present, then the <media> element will only be displayed for the version(s) specified.
This element is used for both PDF and online versions unless another, version-specific element is present (default). This element is used only for the PDF version of the content. This element is used only for the online version of the content.
The height of the LabVIEW file in pixels.
The width of the LabVIEW file in pixels.

The URL of a file containing a long description of the LabVIEW file. Not all readers will be able to see your included media in their browser, either due to blindness, low-vision, or an environment that doesn't support the media. Some media are too complex to describe fully in a few words using the "alt" attribute, however. For media like charts and graphs that are important for understanding the material, use "longdesc" to point to a Web file that contains a full explanation of the media.

tag.name: commentary
tag.description: The commentary tag is used to provide supplementary commentary for exercises and their solutions. This commentary is associated with the exercise itself and may present itself in the form of a follow-up question, explanation, or variation of the exercise.

exampleexample.input: <exercise id="gravity-exercise"> <problem id="gravity-problem"> <para id="prob_1"> If a golf ball and a feather were dropped at the same time from 10 feet, which would strike the ground first? </para> </problem> <solution id="gravity-solution"> <para id="sol_1"> The golf ball would hit the ground first. </para> </solution> <commentary id="gravity-commentary" type="follow-up"> How would this problem have been different if the experiment was conducted in a vacuum? </commentary> </exercise>

div.div: If a golf ball and a feather were dropped at the same time from 10 feet, which would strike the ground first?
The golf ball would hit the ground first.
How would this problem have been different if the experiment was conducted in a vacuum?

attributes.attribute: Defines the type of commentary. Type can be any user-defined value that reflects the purpose of the commentary.

tag.name: preformat
tag.description: The preformat tag is used to insert a line or block of pre-formatted text into a document. This can be useful for situations where explicit line breaks or character alignment is necessary.

exampleexample.input: <para id="fav-poem"> When I was in first grade, my favorite poem went something like this: <preformat id="pre-poem"> Roses are red Violets are blue Sugar is sweet And all girls have cooties! </preformat> </para>

output.div:
When I was in first grade, my favorite poem went something like this:
Roses are red Violets are blue Sugar is sweet And all girls have cooties!

values.value: The pre-formatted text will be set apart from the surrounding text (default). If the display attribute is set to "block" or is absent, then an id is required.
The pre-formatted text will be included in the current line of text.
The pre-formatted text will not be displayed.

tag.name: title
tag.description:
The title tag is used to insert an optional label or title for a CNXML object such as a section, list, exercise, para, or other elements where titles may be appropriate.
Note: The title element replaces the now-deprecated name element beginning with CNXML 0.6.

exampleexample.input: <list id="groceries"> <title>Grocery List</title> <item>Milk</item> <item>Eggs</item> <item>Sugar</item> </list>

<section id="intro"> <title>An Introduction to CNXML</title> <para id="cnxml"> <title>Part 1</title> This paragraph presents a brief introduction to a customized version of XML called CNXML. </section> </section>

div.p: This paragraph presents a brief introduction to a customized version of XML called CNXML.

tag.name: label
tag.description: The label tag is used to override the default label for CNXML elements that use labels, such as figure and example. This can be particularly helpful when translating content to other languages. The label tag does not affect numbering; numbering is controlled by the parent tag's "type" attribute.

table.caption: Figura 1: Este es mi perro Benny haciendo lo que hace mejor.

img.alt: Un perro sentado en una cama

exampleexample.input: <exercise id="science-exercise"> <label>Short Answer</label> <problem id="se-problem"> <para id="se-question"> In your opinion, what is the single greatest scientific accomplishment of the 20th century? Why? </para> </problem> </exercise>

div.p: In your opinion, what is the single greatest scientific accomplishment of the 20th century? Why?

tag.name: newline
tag.description: The newline tag is used to create an explicit line break in a body of text. It can also be used to insert one or more blank lines in the document.

exampleexample.input: <para id="favorite-lyric"> <quote display="inline">All we are is dust in the wind.</quote> <newline /> - <cite>Kansas</cite> </para>

output.div:
"All we are is dust in the wind."
- Kansas

exampleexample.input:
<exercise id="exercise1"> <problem id="ex1problem"> <para id="ex1para"> Name three ways you can conserve water at home. <newline count="2" /> 1. <newline count="2" /> 2. <newline count="2" /> 3. </para> </problem> </exercise>
<exercise id="exercise2"> <problem id="ex2problem"> <para id="ex2para"> In the space below, explain why water conservation is important for the environment. <newline count="5" effect="underline" /> </para> </problem> </exercise>

div.p:
Name three ways you can conserve water at home.
1.
2.
3.
In the space below, explain why water conservation is important for the environment.

attributes.attribute: The number of new lines to be inserted (default is "1"). Must be a positive integer.

The presentation style of the line.
A blank line is inserted (default). An underlined line is inserted.

children.note: The newline tag is an empty tag and does not contain any children.

tag.name: space
tag.description: The space tag is used to create inline space within other elements, such as para.

exampleexample.input: <exercise id="chem-exercise"> <problem id="chem-problem-1"> <para id="chem-para1"> Fill in the blanks: </para> <para id="chem-para2"> A water molecule is made up of two <space count="10" effect="underline"/> atoms and one <space count="10" effect="underline"/> atom. </para> </problem> <solution id="chem-solution-1"> <para id="solution1"> Hydrogen; Oxygen </para> </solution> </exercise>

div.div:
A water molecule is made up of two
atoms and one
atom.

div.p: Hydrogen; Oxygen

attributes.attribute: The number of spaces to be inserted (default is "1"). Must be a positive integer.

The presentation style of the blank space.
Blank space is inserted (default). An underlined space is inserted.

children.note: The space tag is an empty tag and does not contain any children.

tag.name: thead
tag.description: The thead tag identifies the heading row of a tgroup or entrytbl.

exampleexample.input: A game of tic-tac-toe x o x o x o o x o
